f6_assessments.q0: The problem statement from this proposal is the corruption and injustice present in cooperatives and NGO’s from Africa. Their proposed solution is to develop a dApp (decentralized application) with a transparent payment system in which transactions only go through when accepted by other members in the cooperative. This solution already describes an available feature in blockchain technology and Cardano, which is a multi-signature wallet. Different people have a key for the wallet, in this case the treasury of a NGO or cooperative, to be able to send a transaction the majority or the number decided during the creation of the multi-sig, will have to sign the transaction otherwise it can’t be broadcasted. Therefore there’s no need to develop an additional dApp to do the same thing it can done natively with Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1:
This proposal is asking for funding amounting to 60% of the total funds allocated to Grow Africa, Grow Cardano challenge. This on itself is not a red flag, but in this case how the funds will be spent is not described in detail. 200K for dApp development and 100k for salaries and travel. How many hours are needed to have the MVP, alpha and beta versions of this dApp? How many developers will be needed? Which skill sets? In the team description there is only one person as developer with no links to LinkedIn, GitHub or  personal portfolio of previous work done in dApp development. More information is also needed on how the 100k will be spent, whose salaries will be payed? How many hours will be dedicated to this project? The rest of team members should also provide context and information about their roles in this project.
The detailed plan including timeline and key milestones is too vague and short for a project of this magnitude. The possible candidates should already have been identified before asking for funding. It’s not clear the country has been decided either, giving Uganda and Ethiopia as candidates. I imagine they have their own challenges and nuances to consider. There’s no timeline specified for the development of the dApp either, this is very important information that is needed to analyze the feasibility of the proposal.
The company behind this proposal is called In4Resilience based in Sweden. Their website doesn’t contain any meaningful information or proof of past work done in Africa or with NGOs. Their LinkedIn page was created only two months ago and have only two employees and seven followers. These are all red flags in my opinion.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal lacks any real KPI or measurement methodology to analyze the progress and success of the project. “Solving corruption and increased financial justice” are too broad terms to be used for auditing progress. There has to be clear and concise milestone to be achieved in a certain amount of time. For example, having the Minimum Viable Product (MVP) ready in three months, develop a funnel with clear stages to analyze the quantity and quality of the NGOs interested in this potential dApp. Conduct certain amount of interviews with NGOs, in a certain amount of time to determine if your solution is needed as a first step. In general, I do not agree that this proposal is easily auditable through the information provided, I cannot see direct ways to evaluate the process or the results based on what was presented to us.

f6_assessments.q0: The submitted proposal is directed toward eradicating one of the biggest problems that hinder the prosperity of any NGO and their initiatives which is corruption. There are several instances where the funders and charities have found that their funds are not getting utilized as expected and later they would not try attending any other fundraisers making a lot of deserving initiatives never see the light. Thus a dApp to ensure the smooth functioning of an NGO and systematic dispersal of collected funds would be highly effective. However, the corruption inside the cooperative the author proposes could be an area of concern. But if the author is intending to use a third-party payment app to resolve this issue, then I don't see the need for such huge funds for the development of the app. Hence the author might have to take this into consideration going forward. Apart from the very brief solution, there isn't much information to assess the kind of lives this could be impacting and how exactly the dApp will be standardized and marketed across the community to make sure some NGOs start using it.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal is kept to a minimum by the proposer. As a result, it may be difficult for readers and members of the community to comprehend how the team plans to approach the challenge. It isn't any better because the action plan and milestones are lacking. Despite making up only approximately 7-8% of the total, the desired amount still seems excessive. A thorough budget breakdown could have been more appropriate. Additionally, there is no other information available regarding the makeup of the team assigned to work on this concept, except for their names. Considering that the proposal is coming from a newcomer who hasn't been a part of any other proposal from the previous or this round, makes it all the more difficult to assume the chances of successful implementation. The costly dApp creation cannot be overstated enough especially if third-party payment services are leveraged. The community as a whole will undoubtedly rejoice if such a new notion succeeds, but given the available information, it is difficult to draw firm conclusions regarding that outcome.
f6_assessments.q2: As a reader, I assume nobody can really tell where this project is going because there are so many important details that are still missing. Again, this suggestion is not being helped by the lack of information about the preceding study or foundational work. Additionally, the monitoring process is made difficult by the absence of the success criteria and KPIs that the auditors may utilize. There is no way to conclude if the milestones and final goals of the proposal meet the challenge's expectations. Even though a large chunk of the fund is allocated for the dApp creation, there is not enough emphasis on the way the community can track the development process of the same. My suggestion to the author and his/her team would be to go back to the drawing board and break the entire proposal into respectable chunks and raise funds for each of them through multiple rounds as the community might find it easy and profuse in seeing agile development stages as proof for further funds. Also, a detailed action plan with sensible milestones at regular intervals will make the tracking also simple and exciting.

f6_assessments.q0: Africa is plagued with numerous forms of financial corruption and irregularities when it come to funds disbursement and payments. Most ssytems of payment are centralized and subject to manipulations and lacks transparency. The proposer carefully identify these problem and intends to provide a solution that leverages the smart contract capability of Cardano. The proposer seeks to build a payment DApp for cooperatives,  NGOs and enterpreneurs in Africa where all payments will be onchain. The payment system will have suites of features some of which will grant recipients the option and liberty to accept/reject a certain payment option, team should also consider to enable multisig capability where a certain number of people have to collectively sign a particular transaction before it goes onchain. These will ensure transparency, openness and collective consensus in all monetary/financial transaction and decision. This is made possible through blockchains due to their distributed open ledgers. These will automatically give users the needed and required right over their payment systems/options. These perhaps aligns with the challenge category.
